Sad to hear this news about Fred. We also go back a long way. Last saw Fred in SF last year August. It was sad to see how he looked at that time. Another "old timer" is gone!  

Ron
STL

  ----- Original Message ----- 
  From: DMcDonald 
  To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: Wednesday, April 24, 2013 10:44 PM
  Subject: [nihontostudy] Fred LeMond


    
  Dear All

  A long time collector of Japanese swords and one who attended many of 
  the sword shows, Fred LeMond of Cheyenne (Horse Creek, Wyoming) passed 
  away April 22, 2013.

  I have known Fred for over 30 years and he help me understand Japanese 
  swords and learn how to tell the differences between the five schools of 
  swordmaking.

  He was always there to help me learn and I remember back in the 1980's 
  walking the San Franciso show. Fred was leading and Jeff Miller was at 
  the end and I was in the middle.

  First Fred picked up a sword looked at it and bought it.It was a great 
  koto 28+ inch sword with some rust problems.He felt that he would be 
  able to double his money, and did on Sunday.A little bit later, Jeff 
  Miller picked up a blade that I had just set down - He did ask if I was 
  done -looked at it, bought it and then walked across the room and sold 
  it for a large profit.By this time I was wondering what was going on so 
  I stepped around Fred and was leading the group.This time I was going to 
  find the treasure!!!You are right. Very shortly, on swords I had passed 
  by, both Fred and Jeff bought blades.After I whined a little bit, they 
  did help me find a blade to add to my collection.

  At another show I remember Fred buying a sword. That evening he took the 
  blade to his room and by the next day had cleaned up the blade and 
  mountings so that he was able to sell at a profit.

  One show we decided to make the drive together. Coming home was great.We 
  both had bought swords and when we were not driving, we were cleaning, 
  or working on researching the smiths, talking about what made up the 
  sword and why it was an example of that school.The trips will be much 
  longer now.

  He will be missed.

  Later

  david
